subsc: (Historic)Rural water supply and sanitation,(Historic)Rural roads,Irrigation and drainage

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the National Rural
            Infrastructure Project for Guinea was highly satisfactory.
            The project substantially achieved its objectives, its
            impact on institutional development was substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of the Bank
            was highly satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, a broad country-wide approach to improving
            rural infrastructure has a high impact on the supply
            response of agriculture production and service delivery.
            Second, assigning responsibility for project implementation
            to agencies within the existing institutional framework can
            work well. Third, labor-based feeder road development is a
            most suitable entry point for the development of a private
            construction industry. Fourth, sustainability in privatizing
            rural works construction and maintenance cannot be assured
            without a multi-year work program and facilities for renting
            equipment. Fifth, works carried out by labor-based methods
            versus conventional equipment-based methods have advantages
            such as easier maintenance. Finally, in the
            resource-constrained environment of a country undergoing
            structural adjustment, establishment of a Road Fund is
            necessary to ensure the steady and timely availability of
            resources for maintaining the road infrastructure.
